text: history of gastrointestinal surgery or disease
gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption.
current evidence of any lower gastrointestinal disorder such as celiac disease or inflammatory bowel disease

patients with active duodenal ulcer or bleeding or history of a gastrointestinal fistula or perforation or other significant bowel problems (severe nausea, vomiting, inflammatory bowel disease and significant bowel resection)
previous gastrointestinal surgery.
current gastrointestinal (gi) bleeding or inflammatory bowel disease (irritable bowel disease (ibd), colitis)
significant history of gastro intestinal disease that may interfere with absorption (gastric bypass, inflammatory bowel disease)
gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption or the ability to swallow tablets

malabsorption syndrome, disease significantly affecting gastrointestinal function, resection of the stomach, extensive small bowel resection that is likely to affect absorption, symptomatic inflammatory bowel disease, partial or complete bowel obstruction or gastric restrictions and bariatric surgery, such as gastric bypass.
ongoing risk for bleeding due to active gastrointestinal disease or bleeding diathesis.
history of gastrointestinal disease or surgery associated with clinically relevant impaired absorption
previous bariatric surgery or gastrointestinal surgery
has refractory gastrointestinal (gi) disease with refractory nausea/vomiting, inflammatory bowel disease or bowel resection that would prevent absorption
active bleeding or otherwise considered high risk for hemorrhage (e.g. known acute gastrointestinal ulcer)
impaired gastrointestinal absorption
acute or sub-acute intestinal obstruction.

impairment of gastrointestinal function or gastrointestinal disease that may significantly alter the absorption of everolimus (e.g., ulcerative disease, uncontrolled nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, malabsorption syndrome or small bowel resection). a nasogastric tube (ng tube) or gastric tube (g tube) is allowed.
active gastrointestinal disease or other malabsorption syndromes

history or presence of digestive tract diseases, including active gastric/duodenal ulcer or ulcerative colitis or active hemorrhage of an unresected gastrointestinal tumor or an evaluation by investigators of having any other condition that could possibly result in gastrointestinal tract hemorrhage or perforation;
active mucositis or acute graft versus host disease of the gastrointestinal tract
active pathological bleeding.
gastrointestinal bleeding (eg, esophageal varices or ulcer bleeding) within 12 months

malabsorption syndrome, disease significantly affecting gastrointestinal function or resection of the stomach or small bowel or ulcerative colitis, symptomatic inflammatory bowel disease or partial or complete bowel obstruction
subjects with documented history of any gastrointestinal disorders, including bleeding ulcers.
gastrointestinal disorders that would interfere with drug absorption
risk for gastric aspiration (ie; ileus, esophageal or bowel obstruction, active vomiting)

gastrointestinal tract disease or any other reasons resulting in an inability to take oral medication or a requirement for intravenous (iv) alimentation, prior surgical procedures affecting absorption, active peptic ulcer disease or chronic diarrhea
known gastrointestinal (gi) disease or gi procedure that could interfere with the oral absorption or tolerance of ixazomib including difficulty swallowing
known impairment of gastrointestinal (gi) function or gi disease that may significantly alter the absorption of oral everolimus
subjects with esophageal or intestinal fistulas.
patients who have evidence of active gastrointestinal bleeding will be excluded
high risk of bleeding (e.g. recurrent gi or gu bleeding, active peptic ulcer disease, etc.)

impairment of gastrointestinal function or gastrointestinal disease that may significantly alter the absorption of sirolimus (e.g. ulcerative disease, uncontrolled nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, malabsorption syndrome or small bowel resection). a gastric tube or nasogastric tube is allowed.
active pathological bleeding
evidence of abdominal fistula, gastrointestinal (gi) perforation or intraabdominal abscess
inability to swallow capsules or known gastrointestinal malabsorption
active peptic ulcer or upper gastrointestinal (gi) bleeding within 3 months prior to index procedure.
gastrointestinal obstruction
history of rectal surgery or lower gastrointestinal bleed

impairment of gastrointestinal function or gastrointestinal disease that may significantly alter the absorption of everolimus (e.g., ulcerative disease, uncontrolled nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, malabsorption syndrome or small bowel resection.
gastrointestinal surgery in the past
patients with intestinal obstruction or gastrointestinal bleeding
eating disorders (anorexia, bulimia) or gastrointestinal disorders
uncontrolled malabsorption syndrome significantly affecting gastrointestinal function;
subjects with (a history of) metabolic or gastrointestinal diseases including hepatic disorders
acute gastrointestinal bleeding
